instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3302: What is 820-3302? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
Replaced PSU and same behavior

Dissambled board and noticed a lot of dust on it

Remove the USB ports protection and find oxidation on 

<CAPACITOR>C9415</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9610</CAPACITOR>

I tought it was them but with multimeter they are not short to ground

In the middle is <CAPACITOR>C9487</CAPACITOR> which does not look bad not with oxidation but using the multimeter I found that this line (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>) is short to ground

What should I do next?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
What is the exact ohm resistance of the short?
If low enough, voltage injection method should help.

First, inspect <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> filter caps placed near the corroded area.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
ohm = 0.1 

Tried to find injecting 2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C9680</CAPACITOR> and looking and poruing some alcohol on <CHIP>U9610</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> but didnt find anything, since I got an issue on these guys in the past

Not sure what do you mean by filter cap. Can you give me the number? Are it the small ones around <CHIP>U9610</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
Use boardview; look at the caps connected to <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
IR cam can help better than alcohol method.

BTW, remove CPU heatsink first.
And set amp limit to max on PSU, before injecting voltage.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
I am not sure what is filter cap... for me filter comes with F on schematics. I am used to iPhones one. 

Since there are many caps connected to the <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and the NEAR area as you said is really TINY INY TINY LITTLE SMALLY

The pictures below are "NEAR" the corroded area. 

Isn't that easy for you to confirm for me which one are those FILTER CAPS?

I do not have

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
BTW I do not have IR cam =( 

I could check instantly a short if I had one :)

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
Usually, "F" is used for Fuses, not for caps.
We used "filter caps" to name the caps connected to a power rail.

<CAPACITOR>C9480</CAPACITOR>/81/87 and <CAPACITOR>C9680</CAPACITOR>/81/87 are the first suspects there.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning ON
threads.message:
You right

However in Brazil we call fuses .... filters also... weird
and caps we always call it caps even though its function is to filter

The culprit was <CAPACITOR>C9481</CAPACITOR>. iMac is working 100%

Again not needed a IR cam.

You're also AWESOME!
